title: #4: WASM NodeJS API unit tests

labels.name: unit-testing
labels.description: Issue requires creation of unit tests

body:
| - | - | | --- | --- | | Issue | https://github.com/ripe-tech/pconvert-rust/issues/4 | | Dependencies | None | | Testing | `npm install && npm test` at the root level of the repo | | Decisions | In order to generate the python package, a `setup.py` and other files exist at the root level. There also exists a `pconvert_rust` folder that contains only tests. I decided to mimic this structure and re-use this last folder. Thus, I created the equivalent of the `setup.py` for a nodejs setup, creating a `package.json` (and other linting configs). I placed the nodejs wasm tests in the same folder as the python tests. I was not entirely sure on how to do this, but this seemed like a good enough approach to at least generate some discussion.
Finally, I wrote the actually WASM tests, only for the NodeJS API. | | Screenshot | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16060539/105160772-88ec8500-5b08-11eb-9e3f-ec1073d89a39.png) |

title: #4: Python API unit tests

labels.name: unit-testing
labels.description: Issue requires creation of unit tests

body:
| - | - | | --- | --- | | Issue | https://github.com/ripe-tech/pconvert-rust/issues/4 | | Dependencies | None | | Testing | `python setup.py test` at the root level of the repo | | Decisions | 1. Add python unit tests, runnable with `python setup.py test` to test the python API exposed.
2. Run `cargo clippy` on the python API code as well (`cargo clippy --features python-extension`). | | Screenshot | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16060539/105067313-783ffe80-5a77-11eb-8666-a06ea44df901.png) |

title: #4: Rust API unit tests

labels.name: fast-track
labels.description: Feature to be fixed or implemented ASAP

labels.name: unit-testing
labels.description: Issue requires creation of unit tests

body:
| - | - |
| --- | --- |
| Issue | https://github.com/ripe-tech/pconvert-rust/issues/4 |
| Dependencies | None |
| Testing | `cargo test` at the root level of the repo |
| Decisions | In this PR, we make the command-line "tests" we had also runnable via `cargo test`. The code to execute is the same, hence we refactor common code into tests and use it in the command-line binary. Note that the reverse can't be done because the `cli.rs` file is not part of the crate: it is merely a binary. Thus, `cli.rs` can use code from our lib (like the testing code) but the reverse can't be done. Regardless, it makes more sense to me to have testing code in the test module, and, because we want to, to provide the same testing code via command-line, resembling the original `pconvert` |
| Screenshot | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16060539/105064773-0cf52d00-5a75-11eb-8eca-195aa5586980.png) |

title: Clippy compliance
body:
| - | - |
| --- | --- |
| Issue | None |
| Dependencies | None |
| Decisions | `Clippy` is an amazing tool that suggests refactors for Rust code based on certain pattern (for example [this](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/#assign_op_pattern) and [this](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/#manual_memcpy), all lints available [here](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/). It comes out-of-the-box with `cargo` if you install via `rustup`. As such, it is common to keep projects "clippy compliant" when possible. Some changes in the previous monolithic PR were making the `pconvert-rust` crate clippy compliant. After this PR enters, from here on out, subsequent PRs should run a `cargo clippy` (for all features individually) followed by a `cargo fmt` and a `cleanup .` |
